questions.question: According to Ohm's Law, if voltage is 48V and current is 6A, what is the resistance?
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law: R = V/I = 48V ÷ 6A = 8 ohms. This fundamental relationship applies to all DC circuits including PV systems.

questions.question: A PV module has a Vmp of 40V and Imp of 10A. What is the equivalent resistance at maximum power?
questions.explanation: At maximum power point: R = Vmp/Imp = 40V ÷ 10A = 4 ohms. This is the equivalent load resistance seen by the module when operating at MPP.

questions.question: Using P = I × V, what is the power of a module with Imp = 9.5A and Vmp = 42V?
questions.explanation: Power = Current × Voltage = 9.5A × 42V = 399W. This is the maximum power (Pmax) the module produces under standard test conditions.

questions.question: Using P = I²R, what is the power dissipated in a 0.5 ohm conductor carrying 10A?
questions.explanation: Power = I²R = (10A)² × 0.5Ω = 100 × 0.5 = 50W. This represents conductor power loss (heat). Lower resistance conductors reduce these losses.

questions.question: Three 400W modules with Vmp = 40V each are connected in series. What is the string Vmp?
questions.explanation: In series, voltages add: String Vmp = 40V + 40V + 40V = 120V. Current remains the same as a single module (Imp). This is how PV strings achieve higher voltage.

questions.question: In a series string of 10 modules, if one module's Isc is reduced due to shading, what happens to string current?

options.text: Only the shaded module's current decreases
The entire string current is limited by the shaded module
Other modules increase current to compensate

questions.explanation: In series, current must be equal through all modules. The lowest-current module limits the entire string. This is why partial shading severely impacts series-connected PV strings without bypass diodes.

questions.question: Two strings with Isc = 10A each are connected in parallel. What is the combined Isc?
questions.explanation: In parallel, currents add: Combined Isc = 10A + 10A = 20A. Voltage remains the same as a single string. Parallel connection increases current capacity of the array.

questions.question: When connecting strings in parallel, what must be matched?
questions.explanation: Parallel-connected strings must have matched voltages. Mismatched voltages cause circulating currents and power losses. This means equal module count per string with matched module types.

questions.question: An array has 4 strings of 12 modules each. Module specs: Vmp=41V, Imp=10A. What is total array power?
questions.explanation: String Vmp = 12 × 41V = 492V. String Imp = 10A. String power = 492V × 10A = 4,920W. Array power = 4 strings × 4,920W = 19,680W (19.68 kW DC).

questions.question: Using the same array (4 strings × 12 modules, Vmp=41V, Imp=10A), what is the array Imp?
questions.explanation: Array Imp = Number of parallel strings × Module Imp = 4 × 10A = 40A. The voltage remains 492V (from series modules), but current increases with parallel strings.

questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between DC and AC electricity?

options.text: DC flows in one direction; AC alternates direction periodically
AC can only be used outdoors

questions.explanation: Direct Current (DC) flows continuously in one direction from positive to negative. Alternating Current (AC) periodically reverses direction, typically at 60 Hz in North America. PV modules produce DC; inverters convert to AC.

questions.question: The voltage drop formula VD = 2 × I × R × L / 1000 gives voltage drop for:
questions.explanation: The factor of 2 accounts for both positive and negative (or line and neutral) conductors in the circuit. Voltage drop occurs in both directions, so total drop is twice the one-way drop.

questions.question: A 200-foot DC circuit with 10 AWG copper (1.02Ω/1000ft) carries 8A. What is the voltage drop?
questions.explanation: VD = 2 × I × R × L / 1000 = 2 × 8A × 1.02Ω × 200ft / 1000 = 3.26V. At 300V DC system voltage, this is 1.09% voltage drop, within the 2% recommendation.

questions.question: Which wire gauge has lower resistance per foot?
questions.explanation: Lower AWG numbers indicate larger wire diameter and lower resistance. 10 AWG has approximately 1.02Ω/1000ft, while 14 AWG has approximately 2.58Ω/1000ft. Larger wire reduces voltage drop.

questions.question: Compared to aluminum, copper conductors have:
questions.explanation: Copper has approximately 61% lower resistance than aluminum for the same wire size. Aluminum requires larger conductors to achieve equivalent ampacity and voltage drop performance.

questions.question: On a PV module I-V curve, the maximum power point (MPP) is located:

options.text: At the 'knee' of the curve where P = V × I is maximum

questions.explanation: The MPP is at the knee of the I-V curve where the product of voltage and current (power) is maximum. At Voc, current is zero (no power). At Isc, voltage is zero (no power). MPP is between these points.

questions.question: What happens to a PV module's I-V curve when irradiance increases?

options.text: Isc increases proportionally, Voc increases slightly

questions.explanation: Current (Isc) increases nearly linearly with irradiance—double the sun means nearly double the current. Voltage (Voc) increases logarithmically (slightly). This is why high-irradiance conditions produce more power.

questions.question: As PV cell temperature increases, what happens to module voltage?

options.text: Voltage is not affected by temperature

questions.explanation: Crystalline silicon Voc decreases approximately -0.3% per °C temperature rise. A 40°C rise above STC (25°C) causes about 12% voltage drop. This is why cold weather produces higher voltages requiring proper string sizing.

questions.question: A module with Voc temperature coefficient of -0.30%/°C has Voc = 50V at 25°C. What is Voc at 65°C?
questions.explanation: Temperature change = 65°C - 25°C = 40°C. Voltage change = 40 × (-0.30%) = -12%. Voc at 65°C = 50V × (1 - 0.12) = 44V. Higher temperature means lower voltage and power output.

questions.question: A module with Voc temperature coefficient of -0.30%/°C has Voc = 50V at 25°C. What is Voc at -15°C?
questions.explanation: Temperature change = -15°C - 25°C = -40°C. Voltage change = -40 × (-0.30%) = +12%. Voc at -15°C = 50V × (1 + 0.12) = 56V. Cold temperatures increase voltage—critical for maximum voltage calculations.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT)?

options.text: Continuously adjust operating point to extract maximum power from the array

questions.explanation: MPPT algorithms continuously adjust the inverter's input impedance to find and track the array's maximum power point as conditions change (irradiance, temperature, shading). This maximizes energy harvest from the PV array.

questions.question: An inverter's MPPT voltage range is 200-480V. A string with Vmp = 350V at STC will:

options.text: Operate within MPPT range at STC but may fall below in hot weather

questions.explanation: At STC (25°C), 350V is within 200-480V range. But at high temperatures, Vmp drops (e.g., -0.35%/°C × 40°C = -14%, giving 301V). String design must keep Vmp above 200V at highest expected temperature.

questions.question: A typical grid-tied string inverter has peak efficiency of approximately:
questions.explanation: Modern grid-tied inverters achieve peak efficiencies of 96-99%. Efficiency varies with input power level; peak efficiency typically occurs at 25-50% of rated power. CEC weighted efficiency accounts for real-world operating conditions.

questions.question: What distinguishes a transformerless inverter from an isolated inverter?

options.text: Transformerless has no galvanic isolation between DC and AC

questions.explanation: Transformerless (non-isolated) inverters connect DC and AC sides without transformer isolation, offering higher efficiency and lighter weight. They require functionally grounded arrays and ground-fault protection per NEC 690.41.

questions.question: A power factor of 1.0 (unity) means:

options.text: The system is producing reactive power
All power is real power (kW) with no reactive power (kVAR)
Voltage and current are 90° out of phase

questions.explanation: Unity power factor means voltage and current are in phase—all apparent power is real power doing useful work. Most grid-tied inverters operate at or near unity power factor, though some can provide reactive power support.

questions.question: The relationship between apparent power (S), real power (P), and reactive power (Q) is:
questions.explanation: The power triangle shows S² = P² + Q² (Pythagorean relationship). S is measured in VA (or kVA), P in watts (or kW), and Q in VAR (or kVAR). Power factor = P/S = cos(θ) where θ is the phase angle.

questions.question: Bypass diodes in a PV module serve to:

options.text: Provide current path around shaded or damaged cells

questions.explanation: Bypass diodes conduct when cells become reverse-biased (shaded), allowing string current to bypass the affected cell group. This prevents hot spots and allows unshaded cells to continue producing power. Most modules have 3 bypass diodes.

questions.question: When a bypass diode conducts, what is the approximate voltage drop across it?
questions.explanation: A conducting silicon bypass diode has approximately 0.5-0.7V forward voltage drop. This small voltage loss is preferable to the complete current blockage that would occur without the diode when cells are shaded.

questions.question: A 'hot spot' in a PV module occurs when:

options.text: The module is facing the sun
A shaded cell dissipates power as heat from other cells
The inverter is at peak efficiency

questions.explanation: When a cell is shaded in a series string, it becomes reverse-biased and acts as a load, dissipating power from unshaded cells as heat. This localized heating can damage cells and encapsulants. Bypass diodes prevent this.

questions.question: Blocking diodes prevent:

options.text: Current from flowing through the module
Reverse current flow from parallel strings or batteries into a shaded string

questions.explanation: Blocking diodes in series with each string prevent reverse current from higher-voltage strings flowing into lower-voltage (shaded) strings. Less common now with MLPE and smart inverters, but still used in some battery systems.

questions.question: Crystalline silicon solar cells are made from:
questions.explanation: Crystalline silicon cells are made from highly purified silicon formed into either single-crystal (monocrystalline) or multi-crystal (polycrystalline) wafers. Silicon's semiconductor properties enable the photovoltaic effect.

questions.question: The photovoltaic effect occurs when:

options.text: Light photons free electrons in a semiconductor, creating voltage and current

questions.explanation: The photovoltaic effect converts light directly to electricity. Photons with sufficient energy (above the bandgap) free electrons in the semiconductor. The p-n junction creates an electric field that separates charges, producing voltage and current.

questions.question: A single crystalline silicon cell produces approximately what voltage?
questions.explanation: A single crystalline silicon cell produces approximately 0.5-0.6V open-circuit voltage. Modules connect 60-72+ cells in series to achieve useful voltages (30-50V typical). Current depends on cell area and irradiance.

questions.question: Standard Test Conditions (STC) specify what irradiance level?
questions.explanation: STC specifies 1000 W/m² irradiance, 25°C cell temperature, and AM 1.5 spectrum. All module nameplate ratings (Pmax, Voc, Isc, Vmp, Imp) are based on these standard conditions for consistent comparison.

questions.question: If irradiance drops from 1000 W/m² to 500 W/m², module Isc will approximately:
questions.explanation: Current (Isc) is nearly linearly proportional to irradiance. Half the irradiance produces approximately half the current. Voltage changes only slightly (logarithmically) with irradiance.

questions.question: The fill factor (FF) of a PV module is the ratio of:
questions.explanation: Fill Factor = Pmax / (Voc × Isc) = (Vmp × Imp) / (Voc × Isc). FF measures how 'square' the I-V curve is. Typical values are 0.75-0.85. Higher FF indicates better quality cells with lower resistive losses.

questions.question: A 400W module with dimensions 1.7m × 1.0m has what efficiency?
questions.explanation: Module area = 1.7m × 1.0m = 1.7 m². At STC (1000 W/m²), incident power = 1.7 × 1000 = 1700W. Efficiency = Pmax / Incident power = 400W / 1700W = 23.5%.

questions.question: Light-Induced Degradation (LID) typically causes what power loss in crystalline silicon modules?

options.text: 1-3% in the first hours of exposure

questions.explanation: LID occurs in the first hours/days of light exposure due to boron-oxygen defects in p-type crystalline silicon. This initial 1-3% loss is permanent and occurs before ongoing degradation of ~0.5%/year begins.

questions.question: A ground fault in a PV system occurs when:

options.text: An unintended current path exists between a current-carrying conductor and ground

questions.explanation: Ground faults create unintended current paths through ground (damaged insulation, water ingress, wiring errors). The fault current bypasses normal load paths. Ground-fault protection per NEC 690.41 detects and interrupts these faults.

questions.question: Series arc faults in PV systems are caused by:

options.text: Loose connections or damaged insulation creating gaps in the current path

questions.explanation: Series arc faults occur when current jumps across a gap in the circuit path (loose connector, broken conductor, corroded terminal). The arc generates heat that can ignite nearby materials. AFCI per NEC 690.11 detects these faults.

questions.question: In a solidly grounded PV system, one conductor is:

options.text: Connected directly to the grounding electrode system

questions.explanation: Solidly grounded systems connect one current-carrying conductor (typically negative) directly to ground through a grounding electrode conductor. Less common now than functionally grounded (ungrounded with ground reference) systems.

questions.question: Modern transformerless inverters typically use what array grounding configuration?
questions.explanation: Transformerless inverters use functionally grounded arrays where neither DC conductor is solidly grounded, but ground reference is maintained through high-impedance monitoring. This requires ground-fault detection per NEC 690.41.

questions.question: Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) in inverter output should be below what percentage for grid connection?
questions.explanation: IEEE 1547 limits total harmonic distortion to 5% for distributed generation. Harmonics are voltage/current components at frequencies that are multiples of the fundamental (60 Hz). Modern inverters achieve <3% THD through advanced filtering.

questions.question: The standard AC frequency in North America is:
questions.explanation: North American grids operate at 60 Hz (Europe and much of the world use 50 Hz). Grid-tied inverters must synchronize their output to grid frequency and disconnect if frequency deviates beyond acceptable limits per IEEE 1547.

questions.question: A 240V single-phase residential service has what voltage between each hot leg and neutral?
questions.explanation: Split-phase 240V service has two 120V legs (180° out of phase) referenced to a center-tapped neutral. Hot-to-neutral = 120V, hot-to-hot = 240V. Most residential PV inverters connect 240V across both legs or 120V to neutral.

questions.question: In a 208Y/120V three-phase system, what is the voltage between two phases?
questions.explanation: In a wye (Y) system, line-to-line voltage = line-to-neutral × √3. 120V × 1.732 = 208V. Three-phase inverters connect across all three phases for balanced loading and higher power capacity.

questions.question: A 10 kW PV system producing power for 5 peak sun hours generates how much energy?
questions.explanation: Energy = Power × Time. 10 kW × 5 hours = 50 kWh. kW is instantaneous power; kWh is energy (power integrated over time). This simplified calculation assumes full power for 5 hours; real production is affected by losses.

questions.question: A location with 5.5 kWh/m²/day of insolation has how many peak sun hours?
questions.explanation: Peak sun hours equal daily insolation in kWh/m² numerically. 5.5 kWh/m²/day = 5.5 peak sun hours because one peak sun hour = 1 kWh/m² (1000 W/m² for 1 hour). This simplifies production calculations.

questions.question: An 8 kW system produces 11,600 kWh/year. What is the specific yield?
questions.explanation: Specific yield = Annual production / System size = 11,600 kWh / 8 kW = 1,450 kWh/kW/year. This metric normalizes production by system size, allowing comparison between different systems and locations.

questions.question: A system with 12 kW DC array and 10 kW AC inverter has what DC/AC ratio?
questions.explanation: DC/AC ratio = DC array size / AC inverter rating = 12 kW / 10 kW = 1.2. Slight oversizing (1.1-1.3) captures more energy during non-peak hours while accepting minor clipping losses during peak sun.

questions.question: When does inverter clipping occur?

options.text: When DC array power exceeds inverter AC capacity

questions.explanation: Clipping occurs when the DC array produces more power than the inverter can convert to AC. The inverter limits (clips) output at its rated capacity, discarding excess DC power. Higher DC/AC ratios increase clipping but can improve total energy harvest.

questions.question: Mismatch losses in a PV string occur because:

options.text: Modules have slightly different electrical parameters

questions.explanation: Even modules from the same batch have slight variations in Isc, Voc, and Pmax. When connected in series, the lowest-performing module limits string output. Typical mismatch losses are 1-2% and are reduced by MLPE.

questions.question: Soiling losses in PV systems are caused by:

options.text: Dust, pollen, bird droppings, and debris on module surface

questions.explanation: Soiling reduces light reaching cells. Losses vary from 1-2% in areas with frequent rain to 5%+ in dusty/dry climates. Bird droppings can cause localized shading and hot spots. Regular cleaning can reduce soiling losses.

questions.question: Wiring losses (I²R losses) can be reduced by:

options.text: Using larger conductors and shorter runs

questions.explanation: Wiring losses = I²R. Reducing resistance (larger conductors, shorter runs) reduces losses. Higher system voltage for same power means lower current (P = V × I), also reducing I²R losses. Typical wiring losses are 1-2%.

questions.question: Module nameplate power (Pmax) is measured under:
questions.explanation: All module specifications (Pmax, Voc, Isc, Vmp, Imp) on the nameplate are measured at STC: 1000 W/m² irradiance, 25°C cell temperature, and AM1.5 spectrum. Real-world conditions typically produce less power.

questions.question: PTC (PVUSA Test Conditions) rating is typically what percentage of STC rating?
questions.explanation: PTC uses more realistic conditions (1000 W/m², 20°C ambient, 1 m/s wind) resulting in ~45°C cell temperature. PTC ratings are typically 88-92% of STC, providing more realistic production estimates.

questions.question: Bifacial modules capture additional energy from:

options.text: Light reflected onto the rear side from ground or other surfaces

questions.explanation: Bifacial modules have active cells on both surfaces. The rear side captures albedo (reflected light from ground, snow, or roofing). Bifacial gain of 5-30% depends on mounting height, ground reflectivity, and installation type.

questions.question: Which surface has the highest albedo (reflectivity)?
questions.explanation: Albedo measures surface reflectivity from 0 (absorbs all) to 1 (reflects all). Fresh snow (0.80-0.90) reflects the most light. White roofing (0.60-0.80) is also high. Dark surfaces provide minimal bifacial gain.

questions.question: Half-cut cell modules reduce what type of loss?
questions.explanation: Half-cut cells carry half the current of full cells (since half the cell area). Since power loss = I²R, halving current reduces resistive losses by 75%. The module is wired as two parallel half-strings, also improving shade tolerance.

questions.question: PERC (Passivated Emitter Rear Cell) technology improves efficiency by:

options.text: Adding a reflective layer on the cell rear to capture more light

questions.explanation: PERC adds a dielectric passivation layer and local contacts on the cell rear. This reflects unabsorbed light back into the cell for second-chance absorption and reduces rear surface recombination, improving efficiency by 1-2% absolute.

questions.question: N-type silicon cells compared to p-type cells typically have:
questions.explanation: N-type silicon is doped with phosphorus instead of boron. N-type cells avoid boron-oxygen LID, have higher minority carrier lifetime, and typically achieve higher efficiency. They cost more but offer better long-term performance.

questions.question: Compared to crystalline silicon, thin-film CdTe modules typically have:

options.text: Lower efficiency but better low-light and high-temp performance

questions.explanation: Thin-film CdTe (cadmium telluride) has lower efficiency (17-19%) than crystalline silicon (20-23%) but better temperature coefficient and low-light response. This can result in better energy yield in hot climates despite lower STC rating.

questions.question: A string inverter with one MPPT input connected to multiple strings will:

options.text: Find a common MPP for all connected strings

questions.explanation: Strings on the same MPPT input are paralleled at the inverter. The MPPT finds a single operating point for the combined strings. If strings have different orientations or shading, they should connect to separate MPPT inputs.

questions.question: Microinverters convert DC to AC at what location?
questions.explanation: Microinverters mount behind each PV module and convert DC to AC at the module level. Each module operates at its own MPP, eliminating string mismatch losses and shading impacts on unshaded modules.

questions.question: DC power optimizers perform which function at the module level?

options.text: MPPT and voltage/current optimization for a string inverter

questions.explanation: DC optimizers perform module-level MPPT and condition DC output for a central string inverter. They provide monitoring and rapid shutdown while maintaining DC system efficiency. The string inverter handles DC-to-AC conversion.

questions.question: Lithium-ion batteries used in residential solar+storage systems typically use what chemistry?

options.text: LFP (lithium iron phosphate) or NMC (nickel manganese cobalt)

questions.explanation: Residential ESS commonly uses LFP (safer, longer cycle life) or NMC (higher energy density). LFP dominates due to safety, 10-15 year lifespan, and no thermal runaway risk. Both require battery management systems (BMS).

questions.question: A 10 kWh battery with 80% depth of discharge (DoD) can provide how much usable energy?
questions.explanation: Usable capacity = Total capacity × DoD = 10 kWh × 0.80 = 8 kWh. Manufacturers limit DoD to extend battery life. Never discharging below 20% SOC (state of charge) significantly increases cycle life.

questions.question: A battery rated 5 kW / 13.5 kWh can:

options.text: Discharge at 5 kW for up to 2.7 hours

questions.explanation: Power (kW) is the rate; energy (kWh) is total storage. At maximum 5 kW power, discharge time = 13.5 kWh ÷ 5 kW = 2.7 hours. Lower power discharge extends time; higher loads may exceed power rating.

questions.question: Battery round-trip efficiency of 90% means:

options.text: 10% of stored energy is lost during charge/discharge cycle

questions.explanation: Round-trip efficiency = Energy out ÷ Energy in. At 90%, storing 10 kWh returns 9 kWh, with 1 kWh lost as heat during conversion. Li-ion batteries typically achieve 85-95% round-trip efficiency.

questions.question: An MPPT charge controller for battery systems provides:

options.text: Maximum power point tracking and voltage conversion for battery charging

questions.explanation: MPPT charge controllers track array MPP while converting voltage to appropriate battery charging voltage. They're more efficient than PWM controllers, especially when array voltage differs significantly from battery voltage.

questions.question: In a DC-coupled PV+storage system, the battery charges from:

options.text: DC power from the PV array through a shared DC bus

questions.explanation: DC-coupled systems connect batteries to the DC side of a hybrid inverter. PV charges batteries directly without DC→AC→DC conversion losses. This is more efficient for PV-to-battery charging than AC-coupled systems.

questions.question: During a grid outage, a grid-tied PV system without batteries will:

options.text: Shut down due to anti-islanding protection

questions.explanation: Anti-islanding per IEEE 1547/NEC 705.40 requires grid-tied inverters to disconnect within 2 seconds of grid loss. This protects utility workers from backfed power. Battery backup or special island-capable inverters are needed for outage power.

questions.question: An 'island-capable' or 'grid-forming' inverter can:

options.text: Only work with the grid present
Create its own AC voltage reference to power loads during outages

questions.explanation: Island-capable inverters can form their own grid (set voltage/frequency) to power loads during utility outages. They require battery storage and a transfer mechanism to isolate from the utility during islanding.

questions.question: In AC circuits, impedance (Z) is the combination of:
questions.explanation: Impedance Z = √(R² + X²) where R is resistance and X is reactance (inductive or capacitive). Impedance is measured in ohms and affects AC current flow. Inverter output circuits have both resistive and reactive components.

questions.question: Capacitors in inverter circuits are used for:

options.text: Filtering and smoothing DC voltage, energy storage

questions.explanation: Capacitors in inverters smooth DC bus voltage (bulk capacitors), filter high-frequency switching noise (film capacitors), and may provide reactive power support. They're critical components for power quality and efficiency.

questions.question: Inductors in inverter output circuits serve to:
questions.explanation: Output inductors (and LC filters) smooth the inverter's PWM-switched output into a clean sine wave. They block high-frequency harmonics while passing the fundamental 60 Hz power. Proper filtering ensures grid power quality.

questions.question: Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) in inverters is used to:

options.text: Create AC output by rapidly switching DC on/off at varying duty cycles

questions.explanation: PWM switches DC voltage on/off thousands of times per second with varying pulse widths. When filtered, the average voltage follows a sine wave pattern. Higher PWM frequency allows smaller filters but increases switching losses.

questions.question: IGBTs (Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors) in inverters are used as:

options.text: High-speed electronic switches for DC-to-AC conversion

questions.explanation: IGBTs are semiconductor switches that handle high power with fast switching speeds. They're controlled by gate voltage and can switch DC current on/off thousands of times per second to synthesize AC output through PWM.

questions.question: Inverter efficiency typically peaks at what percentage of rated power?
questions.explanation: Inverters have fixed losses (control power, cooling) and load-dependent losses. Efficiency peaks around 25-50% of rated power where the ratio of output to total losses is optimal. At very low or very high loads, efficiency decreases.

questions.question: CEC weighted efficiency accounts for:

options.text: Efficiency at various power levels weighted by typical operating time

questions.explanation: CEC weighted efficiency weights efficiency at 10%, 20%, 30%, 50%, 75%, and 100% power by typical operating hours at each level. This provides a more realistic annual efficiency estimate than peak efficiency alone.

questions.question: Grid-tied inverters consume power at night for:

options.text: Standby mode, monitoring, and anti-islanding detection
They consume no power at night

questions.explanation: Inverters draw 1-10W at night for standby functions, monitoring, communication, and grid voltage sensing. This 'vampire' or 'tare' loss is small but continuous. Some inverters fully shut down at night to eliminate this loss.

questions.question: Isolation transformers in inverters cause what type of loss?
questions.explanation: Transformers have core losses (hysteresis, eddy currents) and copper losses (I²R in windings). Total transformer losses are typically 1-2%. Transformerless inverters avoid these losses, achieving higher efficiency.

questions.question: Why is a ground reference important in PV systems?

options.text: To establish a known voltage reference and enable ground fault detection

questions.explanation: Ground reference establishes a known zero-voltage point for safety. Ground fault detection compares current in positive and negative conductors—any difference indicates current flowing to ground. Without ground reference, faults may go undetected.

questions.question: Leakage current to ground in PV systems can be caused by:

options.text: Capacitive coupling through module glass and frame to ground

questions.explanation: Capacitive coupling between cells (through glass and encapsulant) and grounded frames creates AC leakage paths. High system voltage and large arrays increase leakage current. GFPDs must distinguish leakage from actual ground faults.

questions.question: Potential Induced Degradation (PID) in PV modules is caused by:

options.text: High voltage between cells and grounded frame causing ion migration

questions.explanation: PID occurs when high negative voltage (relative to ground) drives sodium ions from the glass into cells, reducing performance. Factors include high system voltage, humidity, and temperature. PID-resistant modules and grounding strategies can prevent it.

questions.question: The inverter MPPT voltage window defines:

options.text: The operating voltage range where the inverter can track maximum power

questions.explanation: The MPPT window (e.g., 200-480V) defines where the inverter can actively track MPP. String Vmp at all temperatures must stay within this range. Below minimum, the inverter can't track; above maximum, it may shut down or be damaged.

questions.question: An inverter's 'start voltage' is the minimum:

options.text: DC voltage needed for the inverter to begin operating

questions.explanation: Start voltage is the minimum DC input voltage at which the inverter powers up and begins operation. It's typically higher than the MPPT minimum to ensure sufficient power for inverter electronics. Morning startup waits until array voltage exceeds this threshold.

questions.question: Exceeding an inverter's maximum input voltage can result in:
questions.explanation: Exceeding maximum input voltage (e.g., 600V) can damage inverter components, void warranty, and create fire/safety hazards. Cold temperatures increase Voc, so string sizing must account for lowest expected temperature per NEC 690.7(A).

questions.question: An inverter with maximum input current of 20A per MPPT can accept:
questions.explanation: Maximum input current limits how many strings can parallel per MPPT. With 10A Isc modules, maximum 2 strings per MPPT (2 × 10A = 20A). Exceeding this may damage the inverter or cause nuisance tripping.

questions.question: Inverter power derating at high ambient temperatures means:

options.text: The inverter reduces output to prevent overheating

questions.explanation: Inverters derate (reduce maximum power) above rated ambient temperature (typically 45-50°C) to prevent internal overheating. A 10 kW inverter might produce only 8 kW at 50°C ambient. Proper ventilation minimizes derating.

questions.question: Conventional current flow in a DC circuit is defined as flowing from:
questions.explanation: Conventional current (used in circuit analysis) flows from positive to negative. Electron flow is actually opposite (negative to positive). PV systems follow conventional current notation for analysis and troubleshooting.

questions.question: When a PV module is short-circuited, what happens?

options.text: Maximum current (Isc) flows at zero voltage

questions.explanation: Short-circuiting a PV module creates zero resistance path. Current equals Isc (maximum) while voltage drops to zero. No power is produced (P = V × I = 0 × Isc = 0). Modules can safely sustain short-circuit indefinitely.

questions.question: When a PV module is open-circuited (disconnected), what happens?

options.text: Maximum voltage (Voc) appears with zero current

questions.explanation: Open circuit creates infinite resistance—no current flows. Voltage equals Voc (maximum). No power is produced (P = Voc × 0 = 0). Safe operation, but shock hazard exists at full Voc. Used for testing and commissioning measurements.

questions.question: Kirchhoff's Current Law states that:

options.text: Voltage around a loop equals zero
Current into a node equals current out of the node

questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL): Sum of currents entering a node equals sum leaving. At a combiner where 3 strings (each 10A) connect, 30A exits toward the inverter. Essential for analyzing parallel connections.

questions.question: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law states that:

options.text: Current into a node equals current out
Sum of voltages around any closed loop equals zero

questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL): Algebraic sum of voltages around any closed circuit loop equals zero. This is why series module voltages add (voltage rises) and conductor voltage drops subtract from available voltage.

questions.question: To measure DC voltage in a PV circuit, a multimeter should be connected:

options.text: In parallel (across) the points being measured
With one lead to ground only

questions.explanation: Voltmeters connect in parallel across the points being measured. The meter's high internal resistance draws negligible current. For PV, measure Voc with leads across positive and negative with string disconnected from inverter.

questions.question: To measure DC current in a PV circuit, a clamp meter:

options.text: Must be set to AC mode
Must be DC-capable and clamp around one conductor only
Can clamp around both conductors together

questions.explanation: DC clamp meters use Hall effect sensors (not AC transformers). Clamp around only one conductor—clamping both positive and negative cancels the fields. Most standard AC clamp meters cannot measure DC current.

questions.question: An IV curve tracer is used to:

options.text: Plot the current-voltage characteristic of a PV string or module

questions.explanation: IV curve tracers sweep from short-circuit to open-circuit, measuring I and V at many points to plot the complete IV curve. Comparing to expected curve reveals problems: low current (soiling, shading), low voltage (bad cell), low fill factor (resistance).

questions.question: What voltage level is generally considered the threshold for electric shock hazard?
questions.explanation: OSHA and IEC consider >50V AC or >60V DC hazardous. NEC rapid shutdown limits are based on 30V and 80V thresholds. Even a single PV module can produce hazardous voltage (40-50V Voc). Always treat PV circuits as energized.

questions.question: A PV system that produces 15,000 kWh annually with average grid rate of $0.15/kWh generates approximately what value?
questions.explanation: Annual value = Production × Rate = 15,000 kWh × $0.15/kWh = $2,250/year. This simple calculation shows economic benefit, though actual savings depend on rate structure, net metering, and self-consumption patterns.
